<question from>



Carley R
Member since: 20 June 2008

</question from>



<question>



Really tangled hair after swimming?



my hair is SUPER tangly after swimming. I always put it in a pony tail.



I've tried everything from rinsing off and on. Leave in conditioners. Braiding. Lot of conditioner. Leaving it in a pony tail (becomes frixxy and ugly)



what can I do to make my hair smooth and easy to brush after swimming?



</question>



<answer from>



hairbend...
Member since: 08 June 2007
Total points: 3550 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Hair



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Your hair must be in really bad condition for this to happen.  If you say you put it in a ponytail, and you've used conditioners while swimming, then I really don't know why it's so tangled.  Seems quite unrealistic to me.



Yes, the chlorine is really hard on hair.  But a good shampoo after being in the pool will fix that.  Be sure to use one made for removing chlorine.  There used to be a really good rinse from RedKen and Jhirmack that will remove the chlorine coating on the hair, but I don't know if they make it anymore.



Of course, you know that your hair is more fragile when it is wet, so take care when combing out the tangles.  You know that you start from the ends, right?  If you used the correct products, there should be no problem.  Without seeing your hair, and what you are doing, I can't help any further.  The only other thing I can suggest is wearing a bathing cap.  You may think they are ugly, but that really is the only way to protect your hair from the water.  All serious swimmers wear them. Try these:
http://www.headcovers.com/swim-caps/swim...



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks, I'll have to try using shampoo



</asker's comment>

<answer>



The purple hair means it has been over processed.  Did you color your hair at home?  The at home products tend to be more harsh on your hair, or maybe it's just that hairdressers know how to protect hair better.  I wouldn't color your hair again.  I have learned that the "wash out" hair colors that last for 24 shampoos seem to be a lot easier on hair.  Hair can be deep conditioned which will help with the effects you have, but you can't "fix" the hair.  You have to wait for it to grow out and cut it off.  Sorry you had such a bad experience.



</answer>

<answer>



Was your hair in poor condition before you coloured it?  Because dying it brown would not do this much damage on just one application of dye.



What you first need to do is go to a salon and have a good few inches taken off your hair.  Then buy a GENTLE shampoo and a good conditioner and a intensive conditioning treatment.



Use all these on your hair for the next few months..DO NOT DYE YOUR HAIR AGAIN!!!! DONT USE THOSE 24 WASHES EITHER!  If you really need to colour your hair you need to use temp wash in/out colours and just keep reapplying them every week/whenever you need.



Go back to your hairdressers every 4/6 weeks until you begin to see an improvement in the condition.  If you dont want to do all this and want a fresh start now is your chance to try that new short crop that Victoria beckham is wearing!...personally if my hair was breaking off so close to my head like you say it is, that is what i would do anyway.



</answer>

<answer>



Use a deep conditioner every day - one that comes in a big tub that you leave on for about 3 min's.



Trim the ends but don't cut hair too short , just keep trimming as it grows or you will have very short hair.



Blonde hair doesn't show up split ends as much so maybe your hair wasn't in as good condition as you had thought before you dyed it darker.



Dye it a lighter brown with a semi permanent colour that doesn't bleach the hair.



I would suggest you visit a different hairdresser and make it very clear that you don't want your hair cut short, frequent visits to have hair trimmed, gently coloured and deep conditioned should sort you out and while you are waiting for your hair to grow out buy some clip in hair extensions from ebay and then plait your hair to hide the natural ends.

<question>



How do I blow dry my hair straight with a comb? And how long does it take?



My hair is pretty long.



</question>



<answer from>



aℓℓa
Member since: 26 July 2008
Total points: 228 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



this long



http://au.answers.yahoo.com/question/ind...



lol sorry



</answer>



<answer from>



canadien...
Member since: 10 May 2008
Total points: 849 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



With a comb? Ouch. That really won't work very well, and won't really make it straight. Your best bet is a vented hair brush. Round bristle brushes work best. As to the time, that all depends on how wet your hair is when you start, how powerful your hair dryer is, and how thick your hair is.



You should never try to blow dry your hair straight out of the shower, even if you've toweled it off pretty thoroughly. It's just too wet. You'll need to really squeeze all the water out and dry it as well as possibel with a towel and wait about ten minutes or so before starting. It should almost be 'damp' and not 'wet' or no blowdrier in the world is going to have much success.



keep in mind that it takes practice to find a blowdrying method that works for you without giving you any stick-up hairs or funny kinks. I have thick, fine, long hair and after combing it out upside-down with a pick, I blow dry it upside down with a large round vented boar-bristle brush. When it's almost completely dry, I flip over and blow dry a bit that way around my face anf at the end to get a good shape with lots of body.



</answer>



<answer from>



MiMi
Member since: 27 June 2008
Total points: 2644 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



I think you should buy a flat iron for straightening your hair.  I used to do mine with a brush and blow dryer.  Since I got the flat iron my hair is done quickly and is less damaged.



</answer>

<answer from>



Rawrr--☮
Member since: 24 May 2008
Total points: 369 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Blow drying!



After you've washed your hair, pat it with a towel and dry it for a couple of minutes, so it is not completely dry and it is damp.



Next, get a hairbrush (one of those round hairbrushes are best for this - if you're not sure what I'm talking about, I mean one like this: http://shop.fredsegalbeauty.com/images/p...



If you have an attachment for your hairdryer that is like this one, that is ON the hairdryer: http://g-ecx.images-amazon.com/images/G/...
...use this.  If you don't have this, you'll just have to use the hairdryer normally!
Put the hairdryer on high and get a section of your hair on the brush.  Slowly, dry your hair on this section, moving the hairbrush down as you do so, so that section is straight.



Do this on all of your hair.  Good luck!



xXx



Source(s):



Personal experience :)



</answer>

<answer from>



Bill C
Member since: 24 August 2006
Total points: 4391 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



A little styling gel and a round spiky brush should help you get the effect you need.  You need to roll the brush backwards through your gelled hair to get it to rise and fall backwards slightly over the brush and then when it gets to the right height, pull back the rest of the way and let it fall naturally.



I may be a guy, but it's a trick that was taught to me when I stopped parting my hair and started coming it straight back and needed to get a lift in it so it would stop clinging to the top of my head.



</answer>

Without a photo I can't tell where it has gone.  All they may have to do is weave in some blond highlights but I can't be sure without a photo.  You can actually just go talk to someone and see what they say.  You don't have to get your hair done right then and there you could just get some advice.  (Remember when you go to a salon if you don't like the person you don't have to stay once you sit in that chair, you can still get up and leave) Dark brown will hide everything but since you aren't a brown naturally you may not like it.



Source(s):



over 20yrs as a stylist



</answer>

<answer from>



penny.sa...
Member since: 19 February 2008
Total points: 303 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



i thought i helped you with this yesterday?
are you still having the same problem??



the only other two things i can think of are:



Firstly - are you using conditioner on your SCALP and ROOTS? - if so don't!



You should use conditioner on the LENGTH of your hair and TIPS...
and rinse rinse rinse until it almost feels like you haven't used conditioner at all, after a good rinse you hair should feel like it did before you put any product on it; just wet like when you go swimming. Your hair SHOULD NOT feel slippery or gooey.



Secondly - perhaps your hair doesn't like the type of shampoo and conditioner you are using...



Oh, and finally - the ammount of condioner you should be using is MINIMAL no where near as much as the ammount of shampoo you use!



Let me know how it goes please ;)



xo

<answer>



You can try wearing a hair net/shower cap.
Or use a hair/head band.
You can also tie it at the very longest possible place where almost all or the hair strands are equal in length.
You can also try braiding your hair, but it might take some time.



If you want you can straighten it, as in the long-lasting one that you get in hair salons or you can do the ironing one.
If you don't really mind, then just put it down, so your hair, your scalp, and your head can rest.



Source(s):



Personal experience. Observations. Basic Knowledge.

<answer>



My sister's hair doesn't like to curl either.



She puts those soft form curlers in her freshly washed hair and leaves them there overnight, or until her hair is dry.

The "quick" way to curl her hair is to use hot steam curlers.

well i have brown hair i want it to be strait and stay first do i use hairspay and i want my bangs to show

</answer from>



<answer>



well i suggest you get a porcelain hair straightener. i know its a common notion that ironing your hair regularly is bad for your hair, but not really. porcelain does not damage your hair unlike those iron ones, and is actually better for everyday use than using products like hairspray. and with it, you can just iron out the unruly parts of your hair, giving you a more natural straight look, unlike the stiff look that hairspary can sometimes give you. as an added bonus, porcelain iron gives your hair a natural shine. i hope that helps~ good luck! :)



Source(s):



I own one, and I iron my hair everyday. :P

<answer>



I had a similar problem when I was 13. I wanted to cut my hair short but my mom wanted it to stay long. I told her my hair will always grow back, but I really wanted to cut it on my own, not because of friends at school. My mom said I could cut it but she won't do it, and if I make a mistake it's my mistake that i'll have to live with (she assumed i'd cut it bad).



Anyway, mind your mother. All you can do is ask her respectfully. If you can give her reason to believe that you are ready then go for it. But in her eyes right now, she might see your current reasons as excuses.



Ask your mother if you guys can come to a compromise. Someone mentioned earlier a dye you can wash out? That shouldn't be a problem? Tell your mom that if she doesn't like then you won't get it done permanently, but ask if you could keep it up with the temporary. If she see that you're that determined, she just may change her mind.
Hope this helped.

<question>



What can I do with my hair?



My hair is very annoying to deal with. It is dark brown, curly [spiral looking curls] and thick. It also is very dry looking, and when I brush it, it becomes frizzy. I can't cut it short, because when it is short, it turns into a triangular shaped afro. LOL.



I don't know many people with my hair type, but the people that do manage to manage it have grown it out very long. It seems to look good that way. My hair is shoulder length, but cut in a strange way.



First off, how can I grow my hair out, what cheap black hair dye would you recommend, and how can I keep my hair from looking and feeling so dry? [Oh, and how can I keep the frizziness at bay?] Any additional info would also be appreciated.[Such as gothic/fantasy hair styles I could use. That is the only thing I have been able to do with my hair so far, make it look Goth. Lol.]
Thanks in advance!



</question>



<answer from>



Bows
Member since: 18 August 2008
Total points: 153 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



One way you can grow out your hair is by taking vitamin supplements specifically for hair growth [you can find them at your local grocery shop, pharmacy, ect.] or by in-taking foods enriched with vitamins [such as fruits, veggies, beans, rice, ect.]. Another way to grow your hair out quickly is by taking regular daily vitamins, having a good diet, drinking lots water, and having adequate sleep. Also, trim hair when needed to get rid of split ends, and try not to damage hair to much.

A cheap black dye that I recommend is  the 'Herbal Essences' brand. It only costs around 10/12 dollars and lasts long. Go here : http://www.clairol.com/herbalessences/vi...



to figure out which of their products is best for you. [Start off by choosing your desired hair color/shade(click on a hair color and then proceed to the next step)  ]

To keep your hair from feeling so dry you can try using shampoo and conditioner for your specific hair type. Since your hair is curly and thick I would recommend using Pantene's Curls 2-in-1 Shampoo and Conditioner. It:



* Protect waves, curls, corkscrews and spirals while controlling frizz



* Prep hair for styling, leaving it lively, moisturized and defined



Also, a gothic/fantasty hair style I recommend is making it big, so tease your hair alot [the big hair emphasizes the romantic and mysterious look and feel] and you can either leave it curly or straight. You can also just have the nice sleek do, or you can try to get the Amy Lee look. In addition, use dark make-up colors.



Go to:

http://www.wikihow.com/Do-Goth-Makeup

for tips on how to do goth makeup

&&

http://www.wikihow.com/Dress-Goth

for tips on how to dress goth

&&

http://www.wikihow.com/Make-your-Hair-Lo...

for tips on how to get gothic hair.



[[Use wikihow on advice for other things]]



Source(s):



P.S. This is my first post [: 
Hope I've helped && sorry for making it so long.
Good luck !



</answer>

<answer>



I am a cosmetologist, and I have never used such a software. In my experiences, I have noticed that even with all the education I have recieved through beauty school, people rarely ask for a haircut that "matches" there face shape, and that's okay! No matter how advanced the software, the client is always right and they will ALWAYS know what suits them best. A hairstyle detremine by software may not be a style that will be easily maintained for the client on a daily basis, then what? You have a client who is not happy at all.



Source(s):



cosmetologist for 2 years!!!



</answer>

<answer>



ok so you say u know how to straighten ur hair properly, well if thats the case regardless how thick it is it shud not come out puffy! so Ill give u a few tips just in case u never know u might learn summit here lol, spray heat straightening spray onto ur hair before u dry it, take small sections of the hair, and blowdry under, do this all over until hair is fully dry, get some hair straightening spray which is specifically designed to be used with ur irons and now lightly spray ur hair with this, again take small sections of hair, starting from the underneath to the top and straighten do this all over until ur hair is straight! to finish off take some hair serum just a small spot into the palm of ur hand and rub ur hands together so u have an even amount on both hands, be careful not to over do it with the serum as its oil or it will make ur hair look greasy! smooth ur hair straight down, voila poker straight hair and no puff ball cheers Gilly x



</answer>

<question>

<answer>



Hair removal can be of two methods one is epilation and second is depilation First one removes hair entirely and the second one removes the hair thats above the surface of the skin. If you want to remove hair permanently or for a long time, you have to choose the first option. Epilation methods are

Plucking
Waxing ( Sugaring )
Threading
Epilators
Medications
Turmeric
Electrolysis
Laser
Intense pulsed light
Vaniqa

More information can be found on how to remove hair from the above methods on www.beauticianworld.com/hairremoval.html  Depilation methods are also mentioned there

<question>



How young can children be before they get white hair??



My son is 7 and I found a pure white hair last week (I told him it had been bleached by the sun!!)



</question>



<answer from>



Magskers
Member since: 14 July 2008
Total points: 153 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



There really is no age limit on white hair.
Does his father have white hair? 
If so how long has he had it. 
Did anyone in your family have it early?
If those don't answer your question,
it could just be bleached by the sun!
You may think it's white hair but could be really light blonde.
Hope this helps!



</answer>



<answer from>



scotslad...
Member since: 06 February 2007
Total points: 1824 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



There are any number of reasons why hair will lose pigment. Scarring to the scalp from a bump or cut can damage the hair folicles and cause new growth to come in white.

There is a medical condition, Melanin, that causes loss of pigment in the skin and hair.



There is also a hair loss conditions called Alopecia Areata. Some time this will be cause a temporary loss of hair but may cause permenant loss of pigment.



I wouldn't worry too much about 1 hair turning white. If he continues to get more then you may want to take him to a dermatologist.



Source(s):



http://www.childrenshospital.org/az/Site...
http://www.naaf.org/



</answer>

<answer>



Well for the first and second what you need to do is apply chi silk infusion to your hair (optional). Then take a straightener and go straight down with it and the bring it upwards in the direction you want the kind of half curl in. Do this to the rest of your hair and add some hairspray for hold. This works for me hopefully it will for you ;). For the third you can either use a curler or a skinny straightener. Just drag the straightener down to the end of your hair and then roll it up while the hair is in it. Use the same technique with the curler, it should work better with a curler. This also works for me. You can use silk infusion by chi with this style as well it makes your hair feel soft and glossy.

personal experience and my hair stylist

<answer>



-Wash your hair with shampoo and conditioner.
-Apply a styling gel.
-Blow dry and style your hair the way you want it.
-Use a small curling iron and curl the bottom layers of your hair in small pieces.
-Spritz on small hair spray, and gently brush it out.
(not so the curl comes out, but so the curls are looser)
-If they don't stay, use a maxium hold spray.

I hope it helps!

I was Taught back in the olden days never to backcomb your hair with a comb because it splits the ends , to backcomb with a brush will do less damage you have to use a lot of hair spray do a bit at a time then spray when your hair is finished respray after about 20 minutes, we used to let ours go rock hard and then it wouldn't move no matter the weather.

<answer from>



Hippy Chick
Member since: 16 April 2007
Total points: 170 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



On one of those makeover programs I remember a hairdresser saying that there's no need to go at it hard - hold the piece of hair and gently back comb from about 3-4 inches from the roots to the scalp (you can see/feel the hair kinda gathering at the roots), repeat 2 or 3 times, and then spray with a strong hairspray.
You have to do several layers of this, don't try and do 1 big clump.
I've tried it myself - it does work, and has got to be better for your hair than a savage back-combing attack!



</answer>

<question>



Is this possible?



Ok I have kinda long thicker hair that has no natural "way" about it! If I just let it air dry or blow dry its very crazy and kinda frizzy with a wierd wave to it.  Its not curly or straight.  So I have 2 options....I have to straighten it every day with a straightner or I can french braid it when its wet so its got a nice kinda of loose wave/curly thing. My husband and I both really really like how this looks but its a huge pain because I have to have it in a braid all day to let it dry and then the next day it looks good but then I have to do it all over again.  My question is....is there anyway to get something done that would keep it this way? It doesnt have curls so I know a perm wouldnt do it...its just so annoying to have to do this all the time! I need 2 days notice to have my hair look nice!! Any suggestions?



</question>



<answer from>



saqsa_wa...
Member since: 04 July 2008
Total points: 230 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Wow! I feel like you just described my hair! I think you may be a bit luckier than me though. I could spend a couple of hours with a straightner only to go outside for an hour and have the wave creep back.

Have you tried a hair gel for curly hair? I use Tresemme Bouncy Curls mixed with some anti-frizz cream (currently the Dove brand). I put it on while my hair is still wet and "scrunch" it to encourge more defined curls. I let it air dry for awhile then spray a little Aussie Sprunch Spray on it and "scrunch" a little more. If my hair is still too "wet" to get dressed I use a hair dryer with a diffuser on medium heat.

It may sound like a bit much but it's the only way to keep my hair under control. It's also not as time consuming as it may sound... most of the time is just letting it air dry while I go about my morning routine.

Of course with 2 days notice , instead of stressing why not treat yourself to a style by a professional. :)



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks! I am going to try it!



</asker's comment>

have you heard of nits?i expect you have at some point.well they are the eggs of lice.lice are flat brownish grey insects about the size of a match head and they are very infectious and each one can lay many eggs a day.are you scratching your head a lot?especially at the back and the crown and round the ear area?if you are then you probably do have them.you can get some treatment from the chemist for them.they suck the blood on your scalp and can make you feel quite down,hence the expression feeling lousy.its nothing to be ashamed of as they prefer a clean head rather then dirty and greasy hair and there are not many who have escaped them in their lives at some point.children are the biggest carriers of them.



</answer>

Skin Conditions

<answer>



pediculosis capitis!

infestation of the head by lice.

causes
pediculus humanus capitis, the head louse, attacks the skin and feeds by puncturing the skin to suck the blood, it lays eggs (ova) on the hair, close to the skin.

an itchy reaction like mosquito bites, some people develop an allergic reaction, with itchy red marks. lice can be seen by parting the hair, more commonly the eggs (nits) or hatched eggs can be seen stuck to the hair. live eggs are found close to the scalp. lice are passed only between actual contact between infested head to another.

you mush get treatment from product by a chemist or doctor.



Source(s):



stylist



</answer>

</answer from>



<answer>



"Processes like blow drying reduce the moisture content below its normal level and can in themselves be harmful. Hair dryers and other heated appliances first soften the keratin of the hair. If they are too hot, they can actually cause the water in the hair to boil, and tiny bubbles of steam then form inside the softened hair shaft. The hair is thereby weakened, and may break altogether."



Source(s):



http://members.aol.com/hairbook/damage5....



</answer>

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Oh, I think I know this one. Is it the pink and white box that's Boots's own brand?

I've used it. Twice. Works as well as putting perm cream on your hair. It is literally inches away from cr*p.

It smells horrible almost bordering on toxic, it's messy, it's inconvenient (you have to wash your hair several times throughout the process) and in the end it does absolutely nothing but scrape the shine off your hair.

You're better off spending £15 on two bottles of Aussie Dual Personality Straighten + Heat Protection. It does what it says on the tin, basically. Spray it on wet hair, blow dry, spray on dry hair, straighten, done.

I use it and it works immediately from the first use. And it smells nice. That's important.

<question>



Hair dying...first time or root regrowth application?



I'm sort of new to this and unsure what to do.
Here's what my instructions say:

FIRST TIME APPLICATION
This method is recommended if
- you are colouring your hair permanently for the first time or
- your previous hair colour has totally grown out or has been washed away

ROOT REGROWTH APPLICATION
This method is recommended if
- your hair has been coloured and the colour is growing out
- the ends of your hair are darker and in poor condition



Ok so, sense tells me to go for the second because my hair is dyed at the moment and growing out, but does it matter that my hair is a completely different colour to the one I'm dying it?

kayla c
Member since: 28 July 2007
Total points: 423 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Use a good mouse on wet hair.
You can blow dry your hair half dry, and then twist sections with pins onto your head and dry it through.
Take the pins out and shake out your hair upside down.

OR, after half drying your hair, use Big, Fat rollers and let your hair air dry.

Resist the urge to brush your hair, just run your fingers through it with a flexible gel or frizz cream.
If some sections of your hair look flat, just use a 1" curler to curl that section.

I think if you would like to dye your hair that color, go for it.  I think its a pretty color.  Especially if your hair is naturally darker and isnt agreeing with the blonde!



:)



</answer>



<answer from>



Lσsτ Dιаδεм
Member since: 11 May 2008
Total points: 4768 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Jojo's hair was curled tightly with a curler and then made into loose curls.

This is what you do:
1] Section your hair into two sides and take a lock of your hair and curl it. Count to 10 and let the curler go.
2] After you have curled all your hair, tip your hair upside down and scrunch your hair with mousse. 
3] Tip your head back up again and twist your finger around each curl.
You are left with gorgeous hair :D

(It's takes 5-10minutes to curl the whole hair and scrunching and twisting only takes a few minutes!!) x



</answer>

<question>



Black To Blonde At Lowest Possible Price



Just Under A Month Ago I Dyed My Hair Black For My Year 11 Prom And Now Have Decided I Want It Blonde. I Don't Have Much Money As My Prom Cost Me Over £300. I Am Getting Quite A Bit Cut Off Of It Soon (its mid back at the moment i am getting it cut shoulder length like paris hiltons) And Can Only Just Afford This. Any Colour Stripping Products, Ideas, Salons That People Know Of That Wont Cost A Bomb. I Live In Bristol England?

Help! :)



</question>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



A friend of mine did this, and let me tell you first off that stripping black dye from hair is not something to be done at home.  There will be products claiming to do so, but the result will never be attractive and will leave your hair very damaged.  You need to see a professional hair color specialist in a salon to get your hair fixed properly.

Now, the bad news: it's not cheap, and this is precisely why many people try and fail to remove the color at home.  Color correction is never cheap, but black hair is the most difficult color to remove.  Thankfully you have only colored your hair black once, which will make the process slightly easier. (It gets harder if not almost impossible for someone who has been coloring their hair black for months or even years)  The other bit of bad news is that lightening black hair to blonde is a process not usually achieved in one day.  Usually the hair is lightened to a brown and then to a blonde at a later date.  The reason is that if you were to have your hair taken from black to blonde in one day your hair would be very damaged; damage is the reason that some salons are completely unwilling to strip black dye altogether.

Moral of the story: go to a salon and have this fixed.  Also, for your sake and the sake of your hair stylist, understand what you're asking the stylist to do and have realistic expectations.  Finally, DON'T DO THIS AT HOME!  Again, if it's hard for a seasoned hair color specialist to pull off, what would make you think you could do it easily at home?  Good luck!



</answer>

no answerer details



</answer from>

Get you self some hard plastic hair rollers and metal prong clips. Roll your hair up and blow dry it if you dont have to go anywhere you can even sleep with the rollers in (the first time i did this it took for ever but by the thrid time i got all the rollers in in like 20 min and that was doing it myself dont give up). Floding a pillow in half and putting it right under your neck above your shoulder with help you sleep with these things on your head. Also, keep in mind the curls are going to be a lil bigger than the size of the roller you choose so choose a size thats a lil smaller than than what you want. You'll need to part your hair one roller at a time start by makeing a part about where your bang would be about the width of the roller and not to wide (so the hair will dry) from the front of your head (bang) to the back Back of neck) depending on the size of the rollers you shoud have six to eight rollers. now for the side you want to start from the bottom up tucking your finger behind your ear and pushing the part straight back to meet the roller in the mid sectionthen part whats left in half and two or three rollers should be able to hold each half total you'll need about 16-20 rollers. Depending on how dry or oily your hair is is apply a small amount or your moisturizer to your wet hair and comb it through before rolling. If your dont have a sit down hair dryer a blowdryer is ok. The longer you hold the blow dryer on the curls the better. Your hair must be COMPLETELY dry before you remove the rollers in order for this to work properly. You will also need a flat iron for after you take the rollers out to touch up your roots. You can get rollers and clips pretty cheap at any beauty supply store. Oh and dont forget you'll need a nice scarf to wrap your hair in one you have the rollers i usually use one that kind of looks like a net. Good luck dear.



Source(s):



Dr Rachel



</answer>

Thinning out the hair, if done properly, will not look stupid or messed up and your mom might not even notice. <answer>



I did that ! My hair was so thick and unbearable, and my mom wouldn't let me thin it out. I didn't have much money, so I did it myself. I went to my local Sally's shop and bought a pair of special siccors to thin out my hair [it wasn't much money, and I had enough], then late at night when everyone was asleep I thinned it out [My aunt is a profession hair-stylist, and she had taught me how, and I went online and researched]. Anyways, the results were pretty good and my mom noticed right away, she was furious at first. But she got over it pretty quickly [and my mom isn't one to forget things and let things go easily- at all], and we both noticed a huge improvement in how much easier it was for me to get ready and that it took alot less time.



So, go for it! She'll get over it once you do it.
Of course, she'll be a bit angry at first, but, hey, after it's done, nothing can be done to bring it back. The only choice she'll have is to let it go, and forget about it.
&& you'll both be happy in the end because it will be MUCH easier for you to get ready. It's a win-win in the end, actually.

Also, if you get it done well, you're mom might not even notice! I did it myself [but I had no other choice], so it wasn't the best it could have been, and that's why my mom noticed.

Anyways, good luck and all, and sorry for the huge reply ! xD

<answer>



I can't explain the freedom that you feel after cutting off your hair.  It's like a physical representation of getting rid of all your past emotional baggage and making a fresh start.



A woman (especially a younger one) with short hair is a confident woman who isn't afraid to have the focus on her.  Without a lot of hair to distract you, the focus is on the face.  Well, guys may be looking at other things too, but you know what I mean.

There are also practical reasons like simplifying your life.  You'll find lots of new moms cut their hair.

Finally, the bob has become very trendy again, although it's always been in style.  Katie Holmes and Victoria Beckham helped its resurgence.



</answer>

<question>



If I get a full head weave will it look fake?



I am currently thinking of getting a weave done as it is easy to handle and I like a change, most of my family now are wearing a half weave but I want a full weave so my hair is all one texture, but some people have said it can look a bit fake?



</question>



<answer from>



Curvylic...
Member since: 09 February 2008
Total points: 195 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I have never had a full weave as I do think they can look so fake and wig-ish but I have seen some which are well done.
But as good as they look they still seem to look fake as most black girls do not have that kind of hair naturally so you realise straight away.
Why dont you have a partial weave,where you hair is left out at the front and your stylist can then relax your natural hair which is left out to match the texture of the hair u sew in? So it blends and looks natural.
This is what I have done and it looks great.
If you do go for a full weave go for a natural colour and ask to see some examples of the stylists work.



</answer>

SnOoKiE* +GummyBearQueen+
Member since: 17 July 2008
Total points: 2118 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Tagaytay



</answer from>



<answer>



Well, since your hair is dry you need moisture :P

You'll need:
Olive oil
Saran wrap
A warm towel
& Shampoo to get it all out with :D

First you'll need olive oil. You can get it at places like Kroger or Walmart in the aisle with all the cooking oils. Put some olive oil in a cup, enough of it to cover all of your hair. Then microwave it so it's warm. Whenever it's warm, put it on your hair. After you have all the olive oil on your head, cover your hair with the saran wrap and put a warm towel over it like a turban. Then wait until all of it cools down, and when you take a shower, shampoo it twice. DO NOT use conditioner!! I used conditioner the first time I did this(because I had a 2 in 1 shampoo & conditioner) and ew was my hair greasy. It'll still feel sort of slimy, but whenever you dry it it should be soft and fluffy. Good luck. :D



Source(s):



Experience



</answer>

<answer>



Go for the Mayo: Heat up one half cup of mayonnaise until it becomes an oily, white goo and apply to dry, unwashed hair. Cover your hair with a plastic bag and leave on for at least 15 minutes. Then, rinse and shampoo thoroughly.



eat up on an Egg: Separate the white of an egg from the yolk, and whip the white thoroughly. Then add 1 tablespoon of water to the yolk and blend until the mixture is creamy. Next, mix the white and yolk together. Wet your hair with warm water, remove the excess moisture, and apply the egg mixture to your scalp with your fingertips. Massage gently until the froth is worked into your scalp, and then rinse the hair with cool water. Keep applying the mixture until it is used up. Continue to rinse until all of the egg is washed away



</answer>

<question>



I really need help with my hair!!! plz help?



right i dyed my hair using clairol nice and easy light brown i had been growing out golden blond and i just wanted to cover the last remaining bits to my natural colour, light brown. anyway it turned out well but over time it has gone ginger. i hate it! i really want to get rid of this ginger colour but i can't go to a salon as its too expensive. i would be happy with brown or blond hair just not red. what can i do??? plz any advice would really be appreciated. should i just grow the die out and if so how can i speed it up, would it be best to cut my long hair short so it grows out quicker. plz help!!!!



</question>



<answer from>



Hippy Chick
Member since: 16 April 2007
Total points: 170 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Wash your hair in washing up liquid or washing powder/liquid (i'd stick to a non-bio like fairy) - this strips off the colour (they use this trick in hair salons sometimes).
You can then dye it the colour you want.
You really need to deep condition it (washing up liquid isn't great for your hair!) - but if you choose a dye with lots of conditioning treatment that will be good - and perhaps don't choose anything with bleach/peroxide.
If you choose a semi colour, then choose lighter than you want (I chose medium brown and it looks more like chocolate brown - hence the reason I asked my hardresser how to bring the colour up!).

Hope it works out!



</answer>

<answer>



Right well, there are quite a few options here... First of all, you could fade the colour. You can do that by using a hair-stripper, but that can be be quite expensive. I've heard washing up liquid can work, but that could seriously damage your hair. Personally, Head and Shoulders shampoo if brilliant. Its anti-dandruff so it opens up the scalp. Leave it on for about half an hour and wash it off, and most of the dye will come out. Since you died your hair brown over the top of blond, it would take the brown out and leave it blond. This is what I would try before getting any cutting or re-dyeing done. If that doesn't work, I would dye over the top with a darker colour. That's sure to work :) Hope this helps x

<answer>



another idea for a hair style is a "poof". You can take a small section of hair including your bangs or you can leave your bangs down and just take pieces of long hair right behind your bangs. Pull them back but poof them up and secure it with bobby pins.

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I disagree with everyone else. I felt like I wouldn't get a good straight iron for cheap, but I decided to try a cheap one first just in case it worked. I bought a ceramic one by jilbere de paris from sally's beauty supply 3 or 4 yrs. ago for $40 and it was awesome. I have really thick kinky hair and I had a relaxer but my hair would still get really frizzy whenever I did it myself. But this would straighten my hair flawlessly everytime. I used it on the highest setting and it's the only iron I had that never damaged my hair. I'd recommend it before you spend like $200 on a flat iron, I never had to buy another one after trying that one. Just remember to use a heat protector.

molly
Member since: 13 August 2008
Total points: 128 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes I think you should tell him, but definitely do it nicely.  Think about it as though you were in his shoes: you'd want your friend to let you know that you had an unflattering cut, to reassure you that you could fix it, and to do both of those things without offending you.



Offer him suggestions of flattering cuts for people with his facial structure... i.e., skinny men can usually pull off a longer cut (think scene boys with their flatironed past ear hair) or a short cut, whereas if a larger man tries a mid-ear length cut it will highlight chubby cheeks, etc.

Just be gentle, and think what you would want a good friend to tell you!  Good luck!



</answer>



<answer from>



Rebekah
Member since: 30 December 2005
Total points: 2802 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>

<answer from>



wytchey
Member since: 19 April 2007
Total points: 1247 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Henna is always a bit "Russian Roulette", it can go anything from ginger to dark brown.

Having said that, red is actually lighter than brown in hair colours, so if you went and bought (I suggest a non-henna) hair dye in a mid brown, that would cover up the colour you have now and should work fine.  If you go for a permanent with a small amount of lightening in it you could even opt for a lighter brown than you have now.  There are loads of brands that would do this, but check your hair colour against the side of the pack, where it shows what colour your hair will go, to make sure it will do what you want it to do before you buy it.

Asda, Tesco and TJ Hughes all do hair dyes from around £1.30, so it needn't cost a fortune either ;)

Good luck!



</answer>



<answer from>

<question>



Do you know&gt;&gt;?? how to do this&gt;&gt;??



make big curls do i need a 2 inch curling iron

tell me



10 points



see ya



</question>



<answer from>



Pregger
Member since: 18 June 2008
Total points: 640 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Without adding any hairspray or anything (you can add at the end) , grab a 1 1/2 or 2" curling iron, ( I use a really inexpensive metal conair, $9 at target) get a stand of your hair and wrap it around the curling iron starting at the top (by the handle of the curling iron) all the way down. Make sure to curl your hair in the opposite direction by wrapping the strand under the curling iron instead of over when you start (hope this makes sense). It just gives your nice soft curls rather than curly sue curls. Once you are done curling run your fingers through all of the strands. I know this sounds like you will be ruining your styled hair but it gives it a really full and soft look. If necessary spray a little hairspray in. Hope this works for you! Sounds time consuming but it really isn't.



</answer>

<answer from>



pinkslus...
Member since: 26 July 2007
Total points: 2265 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



You need a two inch curling iron, flexible hairspray and maybe even hair rollers.

1. Wash and condition hair with a curl-enhancing product.
http://www.ulta.com/ulta/browse/productD...

2. Blow dry hair upside down  until damp and divide into sections.

3. With each section, twist hair around a roller and secure with a bobby pin. Blow dry hair and mist with a curl enhancing spritzer.
http://www.ulta.com/ulta/browse/productD...
http://www.bestbuy.com/site/olspage.jsp?...

4. Blow dry hair until dry.

5. Going section by section, take out the bobby pin and train the hair to where you want it to go. Take your curling iron and wrap hair around the barrel. The heat will help to keep in the curl for even longer. Go around your entire head taking out sections and curing them with the curling iron.

6. Spray in a "flexible" hair spray, so that you get the hold but your hair is still soft and touchable.  Tousle your hair a bit to loosen the curls up and make them look more realistic.
http://www.herbalessences.com/ca_en/coll...

You should know have stunning curly hair with volume! 
This look will definately grab attention. :)



</answer>

<answer>



It's no worse for it than dying it any other hair color, except bleaching your hair is HORRIBLE for it. The problem is that red pigments basically stay in your hair until they grow out, so if you dye it reddish and don't like it and want it back blonde or even just brown, there will still be a lot of red in it no matter how much you dye it.



</answer>

Well for many reasons but mostly due to the climate they lived in. The sun hits the equator more than the poles, and the temperatures are warmer there. People closer to the equator have darker features while people closer to the poles have lighter features. Get the connection? Over time these things affect your appearance as in colder places - lighter paler things(like how polar bears are white), hotter places - darker dimmer things(like darker hair, eyes, & skin), as a result of more sunlight and heat exposure. And then there's genetics and stuff but this most likely started it. =)



</answer>

<question>



Tips on growing out bangs/hair and how to make it grow faster?



so erm, i've had bangs pretty much all of my life and after constant remarks of "oh you look beautiful, blah blah" from both my friends and family when i pull my hair back, ive decided that i might as well grow my hair out. my hair is currently past my shoulders but not by much, and a year ago my hair was fairly long. as for my bangs, they were short and sideswept, but now theyve grown out to pretty much eye level and its getting on my nerves. fyi; i already deep conditon twice a week, air-dry and don't curl/straighten it, ive got no split ends and my hair is very very soft. so, any tips on growing out my hair/bangs and or how to make it grow faster?



</question>



<answer from>



Wog Chick 16
Member since: 18 April 2007
Total points: 9 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



The best way to grow out bangs really FAST is to eat lots of veggies and fruits & take vitamin A & B , or a multi-vitamin (even better!) also apply olive oil to your hair, this can be used once a week as a mask to make hair more healthier & stronger & longer, it is organic so its VERY good for the hair.

=)



Source(s):



My Experience



</answer>



<answer from>



Emma
Member since: 21 April 2008
Total points: 339 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



When your hair is wet don't brush it too much.
Sleep on a silky pillow as cotton or flanelette can pull on hairs.
Keep deep-conditioning it and you jstu have to wait it out.

Here are some more tips that i C&P'ed from a website

1.  If you have bangs that are shorter in the center than at the sides, wait until you can pull the center strands below your eyelashes, then get a teeny tiny trim (1/16th of an inch) to even all of the fringe hair to the same even length.  Keep in mind that bangs that are all one length will be easier to manage as they grow out.

2. Use accessories to help you manage your unruly fringe pieces.  Adjustable elastic headbands or ones with teeth that allow you to place the band at various positions on your head from right at the hairline to midway back, allows you to control renegade strands.  Experiment with matching baby barrettes that will clip mangy strands up and off your forehead near the forehead area.

3.  Play with hair paste, gel, molding mud or wax to smooth fringe hair out of your eyes.  Use styling products to direct hair to one side or back from the forehead towards the crown area.  Start with a small amount of styling product and experiment.  Add more if appropriate.

4.  Separate the bang hair into individual one inch sections.  Twist each section clockwise and then click back off the forehead with a small claw clip, bobby pin or tiny alligator clip.  Create an evenly spaced row along the front of your hairline for a chic look.  No one will even know you are growing out your bangs.

5.  Experiment with different parts to control the growing hair.  Start with a middle part and clip the hair back on either side.  Or play with side parts that allow you to sweep the hair and clip it to the side.

6.  Braid the bang area when it is damp.  Create a side part and then tightly French braid across the hairline near the forehead.  Mix in longer strands from the sides to control the braid.  Tie off the end of the braid with a chic ponytail elastic, clip or barrette.

7.  Use a clip on braid worn right at the headline to hold bangs straight back.

8.  Backcomb bangs into a mini-quiff.  Use a good setting or volumizing spray and a rat tail comb.  Tease or back comb the bangs to get lift.  Direct the quiff up and off your face. Use a great hairspray for great hold.

9.  Wear creative headgear.  Throw on a baseball cap worn backwards for uber chic.  Try on a cool beret, cowboy hat or newsboy to hide your straggly fringe.

10.  Use bobby pins to secure your bangs up and off your forehead.  Add one of the silk ribbon headbands worn right at the hairline and over the pinned strands.  You will be at the height of hair accessory fashion and will have tamed your bangs, all in one simple action.



Source(s):



http://www.hairboutique.com/tips/tip6439...



</answer>

<answer>



Not sure if you are asking for advice on how to help dried hair or what style to get your haircut....?

My hair was the same last week - over dried due to straightening, and I dye my hair too.  My last haircut was also in April, so I got it cut last week.  Unfortunately, if you don't get regular trims, it means when you do get a haircut they will have to take a little of the length off to keep it healthy.  Make sure you pay for a good hairdresser - expensive doesn't necessarily mean good though.  Find someone who knows how to remove the split ends without chopping all your hair off.  Asian hairdressers are especially good at this - my hair dresser is Japanese and she told me this is something they are trained in, yet English hairdressers never seem to have the knack..... so there's a tip.

It depends on the shape of your face and how bold you are in making a new change.  You could always go for a short crop, or just get the ends trimmed and get a fringe.  Hard to say without knowing what style you already have.

<answer>



It's recommended thay you get your hair cut every 6-8 weeks.  If you have curly hair or straighten your hair it is very important that you do not leave it longer than 8 weeks or you'll get very bad split ends.

All I can really suggest is that you get regular hair cuts to try and prevent damage to your hair.  The body shop do a leave in conditioner (Amlika or something similar) that it's worth putting on you hair after it's washed before you brush it.  Wash your hair as normal with shampoo and conditioner.



I've seen some emo girls with curly hair in fashion shoots.  They tend to have vintage soft curls or mess their hair up a bit so it look like they've just rolled out of bed but dress very emo with their clothes.  If you don't mind being a bit of a rebel and trend-setter on the emo scene you could have a few days off from the straigteners until your haircut.



Or you could keep the curls get a side  long 'emo' fringe and have your hair cut very asymentriacal so one side is longer than the other and I've talking 4" or more so it's obvious that it's mean to be that way.  If you had a very asymentical cut and straightened the long side fringe and left the other bit curly with a few coloured streaks red or purple if your hair is dark you would definately pull of the emo thing and reduce damage to your hair.  A little bit of colour is probably going to be less stressful to your hair than every day straightening.

If you must straighten every day go out and buy some GHD straighteners and some expensive hair protector and accept that you will need to use a bottle a month if you straighten every day.



</answer>

<question>



Is hydrogen peroxide same as bleach?



</question>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>

<answer>

<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



Sort of.  It can certainly bleach things, but when somebody says bleach, they could very well mean something else, such as sodium hypochlorite.

If we're talking hair bleach, you need to actually buy a product designed to bleach hair.  I know a guy who tried to use a bottle of peroxide from the first aid aisle, and it didn't work at all.



Source(s):



http://www.cleaning101.com/laundry/fact/...



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



No. Bleach is 'Sodium Hypochlorite' NaOCl (That's Sodium, Oxygen, Chloride). Hydrogen Peroxide is H2O2 (Thats 2 parts Hydrogen, 2 parts Oxygen). Hydrogen Peroxide is one Oxygen atom away from water.
Totally different elemental makeup.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



no, H2O2 is a caustic bleaching agent, but its totally different from bleach, which is used for cleaning drains!

many years ago, jeff (a mate) had his hair dyed green (it was about 1974) and then one niight jeff did some rather excellent acid...



as he walked past the mirror he freaked at his green hair... jeff dived under the sink and basically tried to scrub the green out with anything he could find... including a bottle of domestos...



well jeff not only burned his scalp rather badly, but within 3 months he was totally bald...



so the moral is, A dont do Acid, and dont use bleach to whiten your hair...



</answer>

<answer>



Why don't you moisturize your hair?? Lack of moisture causes frizz.. a good remedy is a homemade mayo conditioner:

Depending on the length of your hair, apply approximately 1/2 cup of mayonnaise to your dry hair. Work into hair really well and then cover your hair with a plastic bag, allowing to set for about 15 minutes. Rinse thoroughly and then shampoo as usual.

(i would leave it on for about an 2 hours for better results)*

Goodluck!

Kristal

<answer>



First thing to remember is, NEVER touch your hair! it is one of the most common reasons for frizz.
As posted before me, lack of moisture is another reason for frizz, you should use a good conditioner and a gross as it sounds, people with curly hair should only wash their hair 2-3 times a week.
Another thing that would be helpful is putting a good product in your hair every morning before school, just wet your hair until it is damp and then put a frizz calming product in the palm of your hands and evenly distribute the product throughout your hair.
Also, make sure that you never brush your hair while it is dry.

try this for the next couple days and see how it works, if your hair is still persistent on becoming frizzy, then i would speak with the principle of your school to get permission to bring a hair product with you to school, as long as it is not in a spray form then i dont think anybody will mind. ( spray distributes throughout the air as well as your hair so it will effect people that may be allergic to an ingredient in the product)



</answer>

<question>



Is straightening you hair bad for it?



i straighten my hair everyday.
alot of people tell me i have beautifull hair, and when i tell them i straighten every day, they tell me i shouldn't do that because it will ruin my hair.

is this true??



</question>



<answer from>



angry227
Member since: 02 September 2008
Total points: 143 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



you will singe your hair and it will frizz more. Dont go overboard with the straightening.



</answer>



<answer from>



Cheshire Cat
Member since: 21 August 2008
Total points: 1360 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes it is damaging but everything else is bad for your hair too hon

-exposure to cold weather
-exposure to extreme heat
-dying & bleaching anddd perming 
-blow drying 
-hair spraying



All of those things damage your hair. Make sure you do a deep conditioning once every 2 weeks and keep up on getting your hair trimmed.



Source(s):



experience



</answer>



<answer from>



Meme
Member since: 25 August 2008
Total points: 387 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Flat ironing or curling your hair everyday can cause hair damage because of the excessive heat. It takes away the natural moisture and basically fries your hair. Try not to always straighten it every single day, just do it on the days you plan on going out. Make sure you have a really good hair straightener and some hair serum to maintain the moisture in your hair.



Source(s):



I have the CHI and use Paul Mitchell Super Skinny smoothing serum.



</answer>

KindHear...

Total points: 1295 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Hair

<answer>



Depends. You have to focus on retaining the length you have. If you retain your length then you will *see* growth, because if your hair is breaking off then it's not going to seem like its growing. Hair grows an average of 6 inches per year, but *your* hair growth could be more or less because it depends on genetics. You can attain your optimal hair growth by taking good care of your hair and health because they go hand-in-hand. Drink plenty of water and make sure you keep your scalp clean so it doesn't hamper growth. Try to minimize breakage. Blacks and mixed girls can usually use the same hair regimens/products/resources because our hair is usually the same: very curly (assuming it's chemical free).



There is no secret to hair growth because your hair will grow no matter what, unless you've damaged your scalp to the point that hair will not grow in certain spots. It comes down to keeping your hair from breaking off so you can take advantage of that growth. There is nothing that can make your hair grow faster than it's genetically supposed to. I'm black (non-mixed) and I dont' have a problem with hair growth, but I have had a problem with breakage in the past that prevented my hair from getting longer. There are also things you can do to hamper your hair growth like putting grease on your scalp because it clogs the pores.



Protective styles is also something people do to help with hair growth. They wear weaves, wigs, or braids for several months to keep from manipulating their hair. As long as they don't comb, brush, use heat, or do anything to keep their hair from breaking off then they will begin to see length after a few months.



I don't know what websites/message boards you've been to, but I've added some in the sources section. Long Hair Care Forum, for instance, is dedicated to helping people obtain long natural or permed hair. You can get ideas from these places and from people who have the same or similar hair texture.

I don't know what hair type you have, but I'm assuming your natural. I'm natural, too, but natural hair comes in many different textures, and there are some mixed girls with the nappiest-type hair, so they all don't have the type of curls you've seen.



Source(s):



http://www.longhaircareforum.com
http://www.nappturality.com
http://www.motowngirl.com
http://www.biracialhair.org
http://www.blackhairmedia.com



</answer>



<answer from>



Rueben C
Member since: 04 June 2008
Total points: 305 (Level 2)

Hair loss recovery..Any solutions?



I started to loose alot of my hair at the age of 22. My remaining hair is very thin and i dont have a good scalp coverage especially when i wet my hair or use any gel. I have seen many adverts in papers and on the net about hair recovery..such as hair implant,lotions,etc. DO these methods really work? Has anyone here ever had hair implants and does it really work..If so can you advise me where i can have mine done..thanx



</question>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



Use Regaine - http://www.regaine.co.uk/men/about_produ... - however, this requires constant use, & is expensive (£25-£30 per bottle - NHS won't pay). Believe it or not, it's cheaper to buy a wig - one-off payment & it's for life - all you have to do is wash it in shampoo once a month.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



Have you seen pics of hair plugs? gross man
shave your head and live with it



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



There is no cure for baldness. If there was, do you think there would be so many people walking around with chrome domes? Any lotion is just snake oil. Live with it.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



My father had hair implants and to be totally honest with you, he still looked pretty bald. It was a painful process for a little bit more hair and it didn't make him look any better. Don't put yourself through that. Shave your head and embrace your look. It's such a charming look for a man these days. If you don't think you can, go for the hair transplantation which is hair from your own scalp. As painful as it is, it works better than those lotions you're talking about. Minoxidil is pretty good and promotes a little hair regrowth, but like I said before: my own father had hair implants and used most lotions and products available in the market. He always still looked bald. I am sorry if this answer disappoints you in any way.



</answer>

<question>



Does hair grow faster in the USA than in the UK?



The question often comes up "Help! I have cut off my hair and I hate it - when will it grow back to where it was?".



In the USA, this is often for the hair extension business scam Locks of Love, but there I hear two feet is lost, but grows back in just a couple of years ready to be harvested again.  Also in the USA, we often hear of thigh-length, knee-length or even floor-length. They think nothing of hacking this off, confident that it will be back there in just a couple of years.  Whether this is true or not, maybe some Americans could comment?

In the UK, this is unheard of.  I do not know of anyone with hair longer than hip-length, and that is very uncommon.  Much below mid-back is rare.  If someone cuts off their hair here, the chances are that it will never grow back, but stays stubbornly just below the shoulders.  So many times have I seen women in their 20s or 30s with foot-long hair sighing and saying I love long hair, but I cut it off and I am trying to grow it again.  But it never does grow again.

If this is true, then is it something in the diet?  The one thing I can think of right now is Selenium.  This trace nutrient is common in the USA, but deficient in British soils.  If Selenium does help hair grow, then the wonder hair growing supplement might just be Selenium, which is present in Brazil nuts, among other American foods.



</question>

<question>



A few questions about lice!?



I'm training to be a hairdresser and I absolutely love it! Except for one small matter... we get at least five customers come in a day with head lice! Our salon has a system were if someone has lice they can pay an extra £15 per adult (£7 per child) and be treated. All of the staff must know how to treat someone with lice and how to recognise the symptoms ETC. My questions are these, how can I recognise the symptoms before I start to work on the client, what is the most efficient way of telling the client, how can I treat the client the best and how can I stop MYSELF getting them?

Thanks in advance x



</question>



<additional details>



5 people a week not a day!



</additional details>



<answer from>



Angela J
Member since: 14 September 2008
Total points: 152 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



ok, i'm a hairdresser of 18 yrs, some facts, 1) lice don't jump they crawl, so u have to be pretty close to get them, hence kids get them more and the adults tend to be parents, 2) they go on any clean hair, tinted or not.
If one has lice, u will c little red dots behind the ears, where they've bit. Also base of neck. Biggest sign is white oval small eggs on the hair shaft, normally about 1cm from scalp, these will not move as they are stuck on with a glue type substance. To check if they are live eggs then u need to crack the egg between  two thumb nails, if it clicks/makes a crack sound then u no they are eggs. 
Though everyone knows or has had lice at least once in their lifetime, it's still embarrassing, so b tactful, just take them to one side, or to the basin, less obvious, and quietly inform them they have an infestation. When u do your consultation, comb the hair, part it as u are talking and check, less obvious wat you're looking 4. 
As long as your hair doesn't come into contact with theirs , you'll be fine, i've not caught them in 18 yrs.
Best way, and most natural way to treat, and not damaging the hair is to apply lots of cheap conditioner, making sure the scalp is thickly covered. This works if done properly because lice crawl up the hair to the scalp to feed, by sucking your blood, nice hey, so the idea is to make hair slippery and therfore they can't feed and die, and the eggs loosen and with a nit comb they r removed. Leave on overnight, rinse in the morning and u should see them in the bath, if infestation is bad then chemicals will be needed.
But if your boss is charging that amount of money to get rid then he should make sure that he has trained and informed his staff sufficiently to be able to carry out this service.



Source(s):



hairdresser



</answer>

<answer from>



scifaiji...
Member since: 11 February 2006
Total points: 987 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Get your hair trimmed regularly--it will grow faster.

I used to get my hair trimmed about an inch every three months, and my hair would grow over an inch a month. Now I'm getting my hair trimmed roughly every 9-12 months, and it's growing about half as fast.

Vitamins and good nutrition are also a good idea. Poor eating habits and overly stringent diets can cause brittle hair and other hair problems.

If that's not fast enough, or your hair is not as thick and full as you want it to be, there is always hair extensions. ;-)



</answer>



<answer from>



Farina
Member since: 02 May 2008
Total points: 3648 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



vitamin B and E supplements... in addition to fish oils/ omega 3 supplements. Hair growth has mor to do with nutrition than what you put on your head.

Also, just avoid damaging your hair from heat and chemicals. These don't "stop" your hair from growing but they can break your hair or cause split ends, which may prompt you to get a trim...hence slowing down hair growth.



</answer>

who say it's pretty and shiny, I don't want
to lose a lot of that. I never used to straighten in and usually wore it up, unless it was a special occasion or I felt like wearing it down. So now, I'm starting to straighten it a lot
more often, because it looks better than before
and I don't want to damage it too much.

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Redken has a Shimmering oil that puts a barrier between your hair and the sun. There is no actual SPF and stuff for your hair- that's SPF bull winkle is for the skin. The important thing to do is to put that barrier between your hair and the sun. Here's the direct sight to the shimmering oil: http://www.redken.ca/_en/_ca/products/pr... and here's the link for the UV rescue line: http://www.redken.ca/_en/_ca/products/ra... GOOD LUCK!!!!!



P.S. as for the straightening try Redken "Heat Glide" you could probably use that instead of the shimmering oil spray because, again it's the barrier between your hair and the sun that protects it. This product protects your hair from the sun AND heat damage, if you don't have much hair DON'T use too much, you may make it look oily. AND AGAIN LUCKKKKK!!!!!! x] ♥ Heres the heat glide direct product site: http://www.redken.ca/_en/_ca/products/pr... and heres the "smooth down" line site:http://www.redken.ca/_en/_ca/products/ra... for the entire site form step one: http://www.redken.com/international/



Source(s):



I couldn't re-find the site for the facts about hair, which is where I got the "no SPF for your hair" fact. GOOD LUCK!!!!!

Hope this helps, and good luck.

<answer>



It'll lighten the black, but if you're doing it at home, not a lot of those kits/products are strong enough to lift black a lot. Black is the hardest color to get rid of. The only way to do it is bleach. Most of the time, it's best to bleach it and then tone it, as the lightening can cause it to turn reddish/orangeish.

cosmetologist

<answer>



That is a job for a professional hair colorist. Black dye is extremely hard to remove, if you attempt yourself, you may end up with orange hair. See a pro for her advice on how to correct it. she may take a sample of your hair and bleach it or strip the black dye to see if your hair is healthy enough to withstand the chemical process.

<answer>



It could turn green, I'm serious. I had brown hair with golden highlights before I dyed my hair with a semi-permanent color "black"....when the black started to fade my hair was greenish for some time. Black hair dyes are the *most difficult* to color over...I suggest let the hairdresser do the fixing for you. Sorry but there's no natural way to get rid of the black. Black stays like a pimple.

<answer from>



Scrumm...
Member since: 07 April 2006
Total points: 933 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



It will go ORANGE!!!!!

Black is the darkest tone of colour you can get, there are many colour molecules and stages that have to be broken through before returning to a natural brown or blonde colour...

My only advice would be to use Head and Shoulders shampoo twice a day until a natural / lighter shade is reached.. Honestly this shampoo can remove varnish from a table.. I wouldnt recommend it as general everyday use but it is FANTASTIC for stripping unwanted hair colour (or dandruff)..

It should and may only take a few washes or weeks for your hair to be light enough to leave naturally or dye over with a lighter shade..

You could like you said bleach for 10 or so minutes and then dye over with a lighter shade, however the results are likely to be uneven and your hair will be in awful condition.



Source(s):



Almost 10 yrs experience, Senior stylist and Salon Owner!!!



</answer>

<answer>



If you want to naturally have long hair, good diet and proper nutrition is the best route. Try taking a multivitamin...I like Centrum Silver or the knockoff brand (I know, it's for OLD people, but it provides complete vitamin nutrition without having to take multiple pills). They market certain vitamins for hair and nails, but they're not any different in ingredients than other multivitamins. Vitamin E is the most essential vitamin for hair growth because it helps with scalp circulation and stimulation of hair follicles.

Unfortunately, hair grows slower in the winter months, which are coming up, and faster in the summer time.

If you don't feel like waiting for long locks, you could ask for extensions at a new hairstylist...I suggest a new stylist because anyone who cuts your hair to the jawline when you clarified at the shoulders was not listening to you and your desires as a client, and I don't let anyone mess with my hair unless I know they have a clear idea of what I want. Don't be afraid to speak up if you feel weird or notice your stylist is going in a direction that doesn't look right.

Good luck!



</answer>

<answer>



I was in the same situation, I had a fringe cut in March and it's still growing out - an endless wait!!! My hairdresser did a really good side parting cut which after a couple of weeks of styling to the side, started to fall that way naturally. Think of it as the reverse of when you had the fringe cut in - your hair didn't naturally fall into place (unless you were really lucky and your hair is VERY straight!), your hair has to be retrained to go the way you want it. If you keep wearing headbands, your hair won't fall into place, rather it'll stay in 'fringe mode'.
Good luck!



</answer>

<answer>



Okay, i have exactly the same problem. I have a HUGE cowlick which is always going to make fringes awkward because there is nothing that can ready be done about it, apart from shaving it off.

I have a sidefringe and i think that would suit you as well, although your hairdresser may advise against it. You just need to get a thick amount of hair into a side fringe, and that should cover the cowlick by just flattening it with the weight of the hair.



If the hairdresser doesnt do it right, which i often find, cut it yourself to how you want it. Fringes are fairly easy to cut, and from then on, you have to blowdry your hair down to flatten the cowlick. Good luck!



</answer>

<answer from>



lil
Member since: 06 November 2007
Total points: 3540 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes. Straightening your hair everyday will eventually cause damaged/burned/dead hair in the later future. It's best if you don't straighten your hair everyday, but if you're going to do that then you should get monthly trims and use a protective spray, along with damage proof shampoo/conditioner. Make sure, though, that you don't wash your hair everyday because it will strip your hair's natural oil, making it dry and brittle.



</answer>

<question>



How do you clip in hair extensions?



i would like to know how you clip in hair extensions to A: stop them falling out. B: how to make sure the clips do not show ie where to place them in your hair?



</question>



<answer from>



tracy
Member since: 07 May 2007
Total points: 3594 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



When put in securely, they wont fall out.  Always make sure that you have a thick layer of hair on top of the last layer of extensions and dont put them directly next to your ear, always put them further back and make sure you stagger them (like how brick walls are staggered if you can imagine what i mean).



</answer>



<answer from>



sugar
Member since: 01 September 2008
Total points: 188 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



you place them near your scalp underneath your hair

Hannah xxx

</answer from>



<answer>



Dont use them because i found out where they come from.

<answer from>



Velvettr...
Member since: 19 August 2008
Total points: 240 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Take a thin comb , and at the top of your hair, lift up some hair about the same size as the extension, now comb it out so there is no tangles!!  It should be a thick amount of hair, but not too thick, and that is how you get it not to show the clip!! The only thing is is when you put the extension under your hair, if it covers the whole extension, then push the hair over the extension over a bit.  To get it to stay in , put some hairspray on before you put on the extension!!!  Ok so here is the steps once more:

1.  Lift up a thinck amount of hair with the comb, and comb it out so there is no tangles.
2.  Apply some hairspray, and stick in the extension
3. Push the hair on top over a bit so you can see the extension!!
4.  Put a bit of hairspray on top and you are good to go !!



Hope this helped !!!! :)



Source(s):



Had extensions!!!



</answer>

<answer from>



a beautiful lie
Member since: 16 September 2006
Total points: 9188 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



I wear clip ins a lot. First of all you snap open the clip, section your hair as if you're going to straighten the underneath part of your hair, then attach the clip closest to the part under your hair. You will see if you need to reposition your clip when you loosen the hair you moved and your clip should blend into the rest of your hair. If you have enough hair in the clip they should last all day. You have to get used to wearing them because they give me headache sometimes. But if you've placed them in the right part of your hair and styled the hairpieces into your own they shouldn't be noticeable.



</answer>

Everytime you dye your hair it gets severely damaged, more so if you dye it multiple times or from brown to blonde.  My advice is to pick one color and wait for that to grow out before dying it again.

Dying your hair darker isn't quite so bad for it so you can do that by yourself if you want, although if it kept fading last time, then you should either go with a permanent hair dye or just get that done professionally as well so that it will turn out nice, you'll do it once, and spend less than the $145 you would have to spend to fix it again ;)
