<answer>



No hairdresser is going to solve your problem. Since you damaged your hair by frying it for a year, the best you can do now is control the damage and let it grow naturally. I recommend hot oil therapy, continue to trim your hair (it will remain damaged and no glue in the world will fix it to the way it used to be) so it's the scissors for it.
Be careful with applying gels and mousse, don't let it get to your scalp.
Continue NOT using the straightening iron.
Continue doing this until you can eliminate all the old broke and fried hair.
Damage with curling irons, bad haircuts and straightening/relaxing (chemical or with heat) takes YEARS to fix.
Good Luck.



</answer>

Your mother should understand at that age, that blonde haircolor does not make anyone better or more special.

<answer>



why not ease her into the idea gently.

have you thought about meeting half way and trying a nice brunette first?



also/instead suggest wash in-wash out colours. available in varying shades of brown, red and even purple (sadly not black, don't know why) these won't ruin your hair or affect your natural colour once rinsed out if that's what your mum is worried about. and they're great for a quick change for parties or just to try out a new colour.

there's a really good range of sachet's available in boots and superdrug, can't remember what they are called though but they last about 3-4 washes. and LIVE Colour Xpress is also rinse out colour but lasts up to six washes (sometimes longer on blonde) and do brighter and wilder colours.

if this works after a while suggest trying black in a semi perminant.  they last about 16 washes (but mine took longer to wash out), not always recommended for blonde hair and may look grey-ish as it washes out towards the end.  look for a brand that does a dye remover in their range (not bleach).

hope this helps, threre's nothing wrong with wanting a bit of a change.

honestly, the best way to straighten (and keep it straight) frizzy hair is to:



1) wash with a good quality shampoo & conditioner
2) blow dry your hair straight- use a brush with each stroke (get a hairdresser to show you how)
4) straighten it immediatly after blow drying
5) apply a few sprays of anti-frizz hairspray and brush it through

<answer>



hi, im a hairdresser so hopefully i can give you some good advice.



firstly i recommend you condition your hair thoroughly before you do anything to it, at age 13 your hair is very vunerable and liable to a lot of damage and breakage because it has already been dyed previously. you should ask your hairdresser to put a colour one shade lighter than your natural colour (base) over your hair and then have some caramel strips put through it to lighten it up and bring warmth to the overall look. if you have fair/medium/dark skin it will suit them all but with very fair skin never go too dark, it can really wash you out.



hope i was of some help and dont forget to take care of your hair with lots of conditioner,heat defence spray and a wide tooth comb xxx

<original file>11454.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk60941.txt</current file name>




<category>



Beauty & Style



Hair



</category>



<question from>



allameri...
Member since: 19 July 2008
Total points: 549 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



How can i style my hair like this?



ive got the cut, but how do i do the style? mousse, blowdryer???
http://www.ukhairdressers.com/style/inde...
thanks (:



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



Let it dry naturally so it doesn't take on extra volume.



When it's almost dry, rub some mousse through it (buy a good quality one, it's worth the investment), remember that you don't need too much, and that it should mostly be on the ends of your hair.



I'm assuming that by saying you have the cut, you also mean you have the layers. So take a hair Straightener to kink up the ends (do this by running the straighter down the hair then curling it up when you're getting to the end).



IF YOU DON'T HAVE A HAIR STRAIGHTENER ONLY:



If you don't have a hair straightener, then spray in some straightening aid (anything that helps your hair go straight, I recommend John Frieda 'Straight Ahead' for $16.95 at supermarkets) before you let it dry, then run your fingers through it while it's still wet.



Tousle your hair once it is dry, then rub the mousse through your hair. Put some extra mousse on your fingertips, then run it down sections of your hair to give it a 'kink' look.



</answer>

<answer from>



Bec X
Member since: 24 April 2008
Total points: 267 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



This has happened because all hair colours are based around Red. The bleach wasn't strong enough to remove all the colour, so it has left the red/orange base.



Rather than going and bleaching it again (which can be dangerous, and bad for your hair) buy a 'Pre Lightener' (I recommend the one by L'Oreal) and then use that to take the rest of the colour out. Remember that it will still have a bit of an orange tint after you have used the Pre-Lightener, but this will go when you dye your hair to the desired colour.



Best of luck! xx



</answer>

<answer>



After a relaxer, it is important to get a good reconstructor treatment.  Thats basically a deep conditioner that contains protein. <question>



How do u curl ur hair with a straightner?



I know u can do it but i just dont know how
Help!



</question>



<answer from>



CHARMAINE W
Member since: 28 August 2008
Total points: 310 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



the same way as w/ a curling iron



</answer>



<answer from>



charmedl...
Member since: 11 September 2008
Total points: 365 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



clamp the plates near to the root to start heating up the hair, then slowly roll in one direction (preferably the easiest one is up and over like putting curling rollers in upside down), pulling the hair (below the straighteners) through the plates in a curling action. once the hair is fully through it will leave a nice curl :)



Source(s):



hope this helps!



</answer>



<answer from>



madems
Member since: 28 September 2008
Total points: 125 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



it is very simple and effective:
1) wash and dry your hair so it is fresh and clean don't put any spray or heavy products that will drag down the curl.(you don't have to wash your hair each time you want to curl, just got to make sure that you haven't put in any products in your hair beforehand.
2) have a straightener that is fairly thin temp (210-220degrees)
3) grab a small piece of hair about 5cm



4) put the straightener at the top of the piece of hair twist the barrel half turn INWARDS (going into the hair don't twist outwards going away for the hair) and slowly pull down.
5) you can twist the curled piece of hair with your fingers then leave that piece to cool (otherwise it will fall out)
5) you can add hair spray but it will only drag down the curls and not be so effective for as long.
NOTE:::: that the slower you pull down the barrel the tighter the curl.



I hope i have helped....:)
Ps. it works perfect if you do it the second day as well



</answer>



<answer from>



badger18...
Member since: 24 July 2006
Total points: 1891 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I don't know how either. All I do is use a curling iron or I use my hands and moose



</answer>



<answer from>



Tanikaaa...
Member since: 18 June 2008
Total points: 3951 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



gah, i tried, its hard =[



to curl hair:
1. let the iron heat up
2. start about 2-3 in. from the scalp and wrap a small section of hair around one plate, leaving 2-3 in. at the end.



3. twist the straightener slightly in the direction that you twisted the hair. at the same time move slowly down the hair. for looser curls, move faster



Source(s):



previous yahoo answers.



</answer>

<answer from>



Takenfor...
Member since: 26 June 2008
Total points: 1538 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Use Frizz-ease. It comes in a bunch of different colors depending on your hair type. I use the purple one. It's just like lotion for your hair. It works pretty well. Also blowdrying your hair with a round brush is supposed to help. And straightening your hair works really well to make it unfrizzy. There is also a sea-salt hair spray that you can make that will make your hair a little more curly and less frizzy. Just add about a tablespoon of salt to a half a cup of warm water and a tablespoon or so of hair gel. Then spray it into damp hair.



As for hairstyles- I loved pigtails when I was in high school. It keeps your hair out of your face and looks really cute. I also loved headbands. They really add personality and there are so many different designs. Or do twisties and twist some of the top of your hair and hold with butterfly clips (its hard to describe.) For gym I like to wear my hair in a big banana clip. Those clips that have the prawns on the end and you squeeze to open. They're really easy to put your hair up in and they don't leave those waves that pony tails do.



Source(s):



http://www.pebblestar.com/images/product... &lt;-banana clip



</answer>

<answer>



So why do we still have these somewhat odd patches in the armpits and pubic region? Part of the reason is friction. In the armpits and pubic areas, the hair acts as a lubricant between the two patches of skin that would otherwise rub together uncomfortably. The other reason might be that the hair catches the scent which is produced in these areas. In both the armpit and the pubic area, there are special sweat glands, the apocrine glands, which produce a far more nutrient-rich sweat than is produced elsewhere on the body. This sweat conveys quite a lot of olfactory information about the producer, which makes it attractive to mates. Unfortunately, it also makes these areas great petri dishes; hence the unpleasant body odor that results when you exercise for a long time. (As an aside, showering, then brief exercise, is said to be the best way to make yourself olfactorally attractive to the opposite sex)



</answer>

<answer>



Try Indian Gooseberry, Curry Leaves. and vitamins.
The vitamins considered useful in guarding against premature greying of hair are pantothenic acid, para-aminobenzoic acid (paba), inositol. The minimum daily requirement of these vitamins appears to be 10 mg of pantothenic acid, 100 mg of para-aminobenzoic acid, and 2 gm of inositol. To obtain satisfactory results, all three of these vitamins belonging to the B group should be supplied at one time, preferably in a form which supplies all the B vitamins, such as yeast and liver. The three anti-greying-hair vitamins can also be produced in the intestinal tract by bacteria. Thus, taking a sufficient quantity of yoghurt daily and a tablespoonful of yeast before each meal is an excellent remedy for the prevention and treatment of premature greying of hair. If one wishes to take tablets of calcium pantothenate and para-aminobenzoic acid (paba), they should be taken in addition to the yeast and yoghurt, and not as a substitute for them.



Avoid foods such as white flour, refined sugar and all products made from them, Avoid soft drinks, pastries, jams and jellies

<question from>

Member since: 05 October 2008
Total points: 84 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



How to stop hair from frizzing?



Any ideas?



</question>



<answer from>



Nella
Member since: 20 September 2008
Total points: 228 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Straight hair might be the most consistently fashionable hair texture in the past three decades, but curly hair, when styled properly, can be equally alluring, if not more so. The biggest blunder most curly girls make is allowing frizz to conquer their locks, but with some care, frizz can easily be eliminated. Here are some tips for maximizing your hair's bounce and minimizing flyaways.



*Never brush your hair dry: Unlike straight hair, which should never be brushed while wet, curly must ALWAYS be brushed when wet, or at least damp. Curly hair is already naturally brittle, so brushing it while dry will only tear it up. Instead, wet your hair and apply conditioner before you brush it. The viscosity of the conditioner will help the brush glide smoothly over your hair and will make knots easy to untangle.



*Find the right brush or comb: Never brush your hair with a fine-toothed brush or comb. Fine-toothed brushes and combs are intended only for thin, straight hair and will therefore damage curly hair. Be sure to buy a wide-toothed comb instead; the curlier your hair, the farther away each tooth should be from its neighbor. Also avoid steel-toothed brushes. Your brushes and combs should only be made of plastic or wood. Steel-toothed combs are too harsh for curly hair and will make it frizzier, even if the hair is brushed while wet.



*Be smart about shampoo and conditioner: Never buy conditioner or shampoo intended for all hair types. Curly hair requires very special treatment so only buy hair products made specifically for it.



*Always condition: Every time you shampoo your hair, you should also thoroughly condition it. Because curly hair is naturally dry, it is in constant need of moisturizer in order to look fresh and clean.



</answer>

No, No, No, No, No!



That hair cut and color combiniation is very emo meaning it is just a fad. That style will be out played in 2 months or so.



You can not deposit color on color, well you can..you'l just have a huge build up of hair dye and no new results. So yes, to get your hair a light brown they will have to lift it with a certain level of peroxide that will be strong enough to lift the hair. If your hair is healthy enough (virgin hair) it would be best to have however much of your hair that you're wanting light brown stripped to bleach blonde. Once you have your hair that white blonde color whatever you deposit next will come out even and at a shade you're expecting. If you do go this route definitely make sure the stylists uses a toner afterwards to make sure the color is evenly distributed, as this will play a big part in the after math of your light brown color. Those models you see on the L'oreal and Clairol boxes have all had their hair stripped to bleach blonde and then had the box color applied, which is why most people say don't ever think you're going to have the same results as the box because how many people really want to strip their entire head? You run quite a risk of damage.



I do not think you should get more layers in your hair, it's gorgeous as it is now. I do however think the light brown would be lovely and flattering on you but remember to get a full coverage you're gonna have to take the route I mentioned above, otherwise you're not even going to come out close to that picture you provided.

<question>



Ok..Help me understand this "base" color?



SO today i used color fix..and it worked great..my hair had turned mousy brown/green from trying to go from Blonde to Brown...I'm actually pretty happy with the color it came out after the color fix..but i bought some color and was wondering if i can  put these colors on my hair w/out turning my hair Purple/.orange/or green(LOL)
My hair right now is about an 8.3(light golden blonde) and was wondering if I could put a 10.3(Lightest Golden Blonde) or will it turn out too orange???



Basically i'm not sure what Base(tone) color my hair is besides blonds..i suppose yellow? Any tips on what NOT to put on my hair..ie. ash etc...



</question>



<answer from>



MamaSays
Member since: 08 August 2007
Total points: 142 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Ok the first answerer is completely wrong so do not pay attention to that.  A 1 is black and a 10 is blonde.  And a saloon is where you get a drink in the Old West.  Anyway, you can't lift color with color.  in other words since you already have artificial color in your hair, putting a lighter color on it won't lighten it.  Only bleach will do this.  And yes yellow or gold is the base of a golden blonde.  An ash base is a green, a beige base is a pale violet or sometimes a blue.  A warm base is a red or copper.  If i were you I'd have someone weave in some bleached streaks and just gradually add more over the next couple of appointments.  And condition it and take really good care of it because color fix and bleach are more harmful than just regular color. Or they can be if you're not careful.



Source(s):



many many years working in a salon



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thank You for explaining the base colors to me...when i look at that color wheel it just confuses me more!



</asker's comment>



<comments>



MamaSays



when you look at the color wheel, the colors that are directly opposite each other will cancel each other out.  or say you have too much ash in the hair,  that's a green base.  so what's accross from green?  red.  so you would add a color with a red base to the hair to tone down the green.

I have a complextion similar to yours and my hair color is about the same as the one you chose. I just got my hair cut recently and had it layered (keeping my long and tapered). it worked out great-the cut gave me lots of volume and I get a ton of compliments when i curl it w/hot rollers then shake it up for volume. w/blow drying it takes about 30-45 mins to do my hair.



good luck w/whatever you choose!!

Ronda B

<answer>



You should be fine to dye it all over.  You will have some strands that are lighter then others but it will just look like natural variations in your hair color.  I actually did this myself and was very please how it came out.  I went from blonde to a medium brown.



</answer>



<answer from>



autumncu...
Member since: 12 September 2008
Total points: 671 (Level 2)



Contributing In:



Hair



</answer from>



<answer>



Your best bet is to go to the salon and have it done.  Going from such a light color back to something more natural is a two step process.  If you do it on your own, the color will not take properly and will most likely be a greenish mucky color.  Before you have it done, get a full consultation. Because this very drastic change is color correction, and it really helps if you and the stylist are on the same page completely, and they know what condition your hair is in, how long you have been lightening it, and why you want a this change.



Source(s):



I do hair



</answer>

<question>



Can bleaching make jet black dyed hair A LITTLE lighter?



lighter like THE DARKEST BROWN?
My hair is black with a little blue&red tint under light.
my hairdresser said he might bleach it A LITTLE and without any damage and MIGHT make it incredibly dark brown?
is this possible?



</question>



<answer from>



Ta Da~
Member since: 22 October 2007
Total points: 3828 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



wish I could show you my hair, I've been bleaching and lifting my hair platinum blonde for the past two days now, but I've been working towards it for about a month. Its blonde and black and has the skunk affect. You can achieve whatever color you want, it just takes time, but expect some damage to your hair, bleaching will always damage your hair. BTW whenever you add color it's not as damaging and might even give it a healthier look.



</answer>



<answer from>



lov.ely
Member since: 07 August 2008
Total points: 283 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



if you want to make your hair even just a tiny bit lighter, then you'll have to bleach it. But the thing is you cant just put a little bit of bleach in and it will go a lighter shade of your natural hair color. Bleach has its own color so you could end up having a greenish or grey tinge to your hair. If you are game, then get the hair dresser to put some bleach in your hair as a lightener, then get them to put a dark toner on it and you will get lovely dark brown hair. Alternatively, you can get highlights to make your hair lighter without really any damage. Hope i helped xxx



</answer>

anonymous :)

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



yes it is okay, as long as it says for color-treated hair.



as for how long the dye will last, it depends on the kind of dye. permanent dye lasts for about 6-8 weeks (until you need a root touch-up). semi-permanent dye lasts for about 6 weeks until you need to totally redo it. i could be wrong about the last one, but im sure its between 4-6 weeks. semi-permanent also washes out slightly as the days progress.

<answer from>



Ania
Member since: 25 April 2008
Total points: 1880 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes, sodium laureth sulfate is an irritant. Here are some other irritants commonly found in shampoos:
* propylene glycol or glycol– a petrochemical used because it is cheap
* cetearyl alcohol – emulsifier that can be synthetic or natural
* methylparaben or propylparaben – typical synthetic preservatives
* distearate – this is polyethylene glycol or polypropylene glycol which are petrochemicals
* isopropyl alcohol – used as a cheap solvent to carry synthetic oils.



Here is a natural shampoo that you can make. This formulation is something that I have been using for many years. First collect the following items:



4 oz of castile soap with any scent is that available – plain, peppermint, eucalyptus.



½ oz of rosemary - stimulates the hair follicles and helps to prevent premature baldness



½ oz of sage – has antioxidants and keeps things from spoiling and is antibacterial



½ oz of nettles – acts as a blood purifier, blood stimulator, contains a large source of nutrients for hair growth



½ of lavender – controls the production of sebaceous gland oil and reduces itchy and flaky scalp conditions



2000 mg of MSM – provides organic sulfur to your scalp, which improves the health and strength of your hair. It also helps to drive herbal nutrient into the skin and follicles where they can do the most good.



one empty 8 oz plastic bottle, or any other empty shampoo or soap bottle.



Mix the herbs in a mason jar, which has a lid. Boil 2 cups of distilled water. Add 3 heaping tablespoons of the mixed herbs into the boiling water. Pull the boiling water and herbs off the stove. Let the herb mixture sit for 30 – 40 minutes. Put the 2000mg of MSM into the herb mixture after 30 minutes of cooling. After 40 minutes and the MSM is melted, strain the herbal mixture into a bowl.



Pour 2 to 2 1/2 oz of strained herbal tea into the 8 oz plastic bottle. Now, pour the 4 oz of castile soap into the 8 oz plastic bottle. Cap the bottle and shake to mix the ingredients.



The shampoo is now finished and ready for use. Use this as a base for all of the shampoos you make. You can add different herbs as you learn what these herbs do and how they help your hair. You can vary the ingredients according to your taste. But now you have a shampoo that has no additives that can harm you.



Source(s):



http://ezinearticles.com/?Making-Your-Ow...



</answer>

<answer from>



just lisa & proud of it!!!
Member since: 15 October 2006
Total points: 774 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



To the best of my knowledge I believe dandruff is caused by many different things.  You could have a dry scalp, which can be caused by the products you use, or over processing, or blow drying or a combination of all the above. Could be the gel or mousse or hair spray you use.  You could try switching shampoo, or conditioner, gel hair spray.  Try the kind specifically for dry scalp. Or try dandruff shampoo for awhile.  It could be caused by your environment or even your air conditioning or heating unit in your home.  The point is that something you are using or living in is the cause of this annoying problem.  If you live in a particularly dry climate or perhaps very humid climate your scalp could be affected.  If your air conditioner or heater keeps the air too dry in your home your scalp could become dry.  If you change your hair grooming products and this does not help then try purchasing a dehumidifier for your home and see if this helps.  Otherwise there are some good dandruff shampoos out there.  For some people dandruff is just a temporary side effect of one of the above mentioned causes or a combination and will go away once you figure out what caused it and change.  Unfortunately, though for some it is something you must learn to live with and the embarrassing flakes can be kept at bay with proper hair care with dandruff products.  I am almost sure that for you though the answer will be found in changing your hair care regimen completely for awhile until the flakes go away.  no perms for awhile and less blow drying and changing styling products until you find the combination that works for you without overdrying your scalp.  Hope this helps....good luck



</answer>

<answer>



If you can't go to someone to get your roots done and you don't know how to do them yourself then in my opinion your safest plan of action would certainly be to buy a home coloring kit closest to your natural color and color your hair. <answer from>



ryegnsre
Member since: 04 August 2007
Total points: 315 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



1. Swear by leave-in conditioner. Slather it on every morning before going outside, to combat dryness.



2. Protect hair from the sun. This is especially important if you color your hair! Use a spray-on UV protectant over your leave-in conditioner to prevent the sun's rays from turning your hair a brassy shade.



3. Use salt as a styling aid. Saltwater gives hair texture and allows it to better hold a style, especially key for lank locks. Take advantage by skipping the shampoo after the beach, then scrunching as you dry hair with a diffuser.



4. Trim before summer. Summer tends to make hair dry, so this process will speed up on hair with already-dead ends in need of a cut. Trimming before the summer minimizes damage by removing unhealthy ends before you hit the sun.



5. Try braids. They're too youthful for the office, but braided pigtails look fresh and energetic at the beach. Simply part hair down the middle, braid each side, and secure.



6. Apply styling paste to short hair. A gummy paste will give short cuts hold and definition, plus protect them from the sun and chlorine. Smooth onto dry hair before going outside.



7. Sport a scarf. It has a decidedly Jackie O. feel and protects hair at the same time: Tie a long headscarf over hair, letting the ends dangle.



8. Swear off blowdryers. While you're at the beach, vow to air-dry your hair. Using a blowdryer after a day in the sun can make your hair doubly damaged.



9. Don't leave home without a wide-tooth comb. While saltwater is a good styling aid, it can leave hair knotted and clumpy. Spritz a bit of your UV protectant onto the comb's teeth and run it through strands after every swim to prevent those knots.



10. Add an accessory. It's simple but chic: A bright, beachy pony holder gives flair and style to even the simplest swimsuit.



Source(s):



http://www.lhj.com/lhj/story.jhtml?story...



</answer>



<answer from>



Jenn
Member since: 25 April 2007
Total points: 5405 (Level 5)

</answer from>

lol i like this look a lot and i do it often with garnier fructis beach hair sculpting stuff...its easy.
http://www.garnierusa.com/_en/_us/progra...
just click beach hair, the blonde on the left...and for a diff one that is similar click the runway volume pic... or if u dont have time in the morning to do that look....set ur hair in large rollars...like about the size of a fifth of ur face after taking ur shower..by morning they should be dry, if not then just blow dry on low heat for a little bit of time, sometimes thick hair will still be wet at he ends...take em down and ruffle them up a bit and put some shine serum in ur hair, only a tiny amount not a lot so that some of those cirls come out. instaed of being really frizzy...for a few defined ones just twist/twirl small chunks of hair that u want mroe defined a little bit.

<question>



just colured hair care  ?????



ive just got half a head of  blonde foils put into my brown hair



its the 1st time that i have ever had foils and it looks great:)
i washed my hair and then blowdryed and then straightened it right before i went to the hair dressers was that bad ?



they put toner in it after



how can i care for my hair and will it fade ??
how quick will be re-groth ??
should i use garnier fruptis or herbal essances shampoo +condider for coloured hair ??



and yeh ive probbally spelt some words wrong



</question>



<answer from>



Moi
Member since: 29 July 2007
Total points: 252 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I don't think that your blowdrying/straightening beforehand would have done too much damage really.



Blonde shouldn't fade, as you have essentially just had the colour stripped from your hair, not had another colour put on top of it.
You could use a colour-specific shampoo/conditioner if you wanted, but I would personally use one for coloured/dry or damaged hair because the bleach they have used to lighten your hair is not very good for it.



regrowth depends on the rate at which your hair grows, but i wouldn't worry about it too much, as all you have to do when it gets too bad is go back to the hairdresser and they'll put in some more foils to cover it up.



Have fun with your newly blonde hair!



Source(s):



In the process of becoming blonde (again).



</answer>



<answer from>



Katie
Member since: 22 September 2008
Total points: 99 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



it will fade within a few weeks the colour will be there but it wont look as good. Buy a few of them wash in wash out packet dyes normally 40p-£1 and put that through your hair every week. thats what my hair dresser told me and it really works well. Everyones hair grows diffrently so its hard to say. The best shampoo to use is charles worthingtons .. hope that helps!



</answer>



<answer from>



Jane B
Member since: 04 October 2008
Total points: 192 (Level 1)

<answer>



Well blonde doesn't really fade.



But if you're worried about it going green/too yellow, then I suggest using a purple coloured toner. You can get it in Priceline or chemists or any stores like that. You only need to use it about once a week to keep it a nice blonde, too much & it turns blue.



& make sure you wash it all out.



I washed my hair really quickly before school photos last year & its all clumpy & horrible! & it was year 12 photo. =[
But otherwise it should look really nice.

<answer>



Apparently the more often you wash your hair, the oilier it can become because when you wash it you are stripping it of its natural oils and to fix this you produce more oil.. giving it the oily look.



Maybe try washing it every 3 or so days and see if it makes a difference.



Also the best trick out there haha.. put a bit of talcom powder or baby powder in your hair where it looks oily and rub it in. It acts almost as a dry shampoo and gets rid of the oiliness. Its awesome for when you dont have enough time to wash your hair. Just make sure you rub it in properly or else your hair can look a bit grey.



Hope this helps!



</answer>

<answer>



For one thing if you think youre going to have time for (2) showers a day wihle in your in training - think again.  I was an Army chick and we got one shower and that was with 6 showerheads, about 30 of us and 15 min.  You dont have time to blow dry anything.  you take showers at nite for the most part.



I am not sure if you are male or female...guys...you'll have a whole new haircut courtesy of the R.M.



A lot of the girls cut their hair short for basic and let it grow after that.  I didnt as my hair was easy to keep above my collar.  RAF might have different regulations as us Yanks.



The military has no room for prima donna's...



I would think they'd give you a short military cut for training.  If youre a girl...how is it that you have straight and puffy hair??  straight hair does not tend to have afro like qualities...



Dont you guys wear caps or berets?  most military personnel do...



to recap: guy - you'll be getting your haircut anyway for hygiene and uniformity...if they dont do it- you do it.



girl: get a better hair cut for training.  use gel or a smoothing gel...



you can wear gel in training- you just cant go crazy style salon- something like a pomade should help.

<answer>



Aww man, glue extensions are the MOST damaging to your hair, it ruins your natural hair and looks horrible.



I had the weft hair extensions glued in and they wripped half of my hair out..literally.



Because my hair's thinner and shorter now I still wear them, so the best ones I have tried are...



Hair weaving (when you buy a natural human hair weft and have it weaved into your head by a professional, a lot of hairdressers do it now) it causes no damage, and they're in your head for about 4-6 weeks before you need them tightened or taken out).



Hair weft with clips - You can style your natural hair, then clip these into your head, and there is some good ones out there.



I buy mine from a guy on ebay...



http://stores.ebay.co.uk/MiSS-WORLD-HAIR...



They are extremely cheap and extremely good!



These don't ruin your hair and you can take them out when you like.



The ring extensions aren't great and you can see them more than these.



Whatever you do, don't be tempted to glue them in again, there's plenty of other options.



XXXXX

<question>



Is washing your hair everyday bad for it?



can i still get my hair wet with water everyday in the shower just not shampoo or conditioner? or do i have to wear a shower cap or something?



</question>



<answer from>



miniaxwi...
Member since: 28 August 2008
Total points: 381 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Getting your hair wet is not going to hurt it.However, washing it every day will. Each time you wash your hair you wash out all the natural oils from it which in time will dry your hair out.If you feel the need to wear a shower cap you can however it is not necessary .



</answer>



<asker's comment>



thanks, thats what i thought =) plus it looks like you have curly hair as i do, so im sure you know what your talking about!



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



sugarnca...
Member since: 04 September 2007
Total points: 218 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



If you wash your hair everyday, you are going to strip it of its natural oils && it will get greasy and gross fast.It also can damage the hair and make it brittle and easy to break.



As for getting it wet, i would recommend using a shower cap. If your hair is getting wet just a small bit by the spray of the shower/tap, then it would be okay. I wouldn't recommend putting your head/hair directly under the water, as it too can make it go gross.



</answer>

<question>



Hair extension question?



Hi,



I am thinking about whether to get hair extensions, I found the place where I want to get them done and the method they use is "fusion bonding" does anyone know how this works and if it hurts?



Thanks



</question>



<answer from>



the_char...
Member since: 05 December 2007
Total points: 1486 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Hair



</answer from>



<answer>



The basic concept behind fusion bonding is to fuse the extension with the keratin protein of the natural hair, strand by strand. In this process the weft is attached to the hair root using bonding glue with the help of heated adhesive sticks which are create specially for this purpose.Such hair extensions are of different types such as hot and cold fusion according to slight detours from the elementary procedure outlined above. Wefts or single strands can be used for hair extension purposes.
personally i wouldnt get this done isnt good for your hair
all the best



</answer>



<answer from>



Brunette &&& British :) ♥
Member since: 20 May 2008
Total points: 1682 (Level 3)



</answer from>

</answer>

fusion bonding in my opinion is the best because they last a long time. on the end of the extention is a karenteen tip wich is what hair is made of and they use this tool to melt that onto a tiny piece of your real hair. then the roll it with there finger tips to make sure it stays.



this method is prolly the least pain full putitng in and taking out.



good luck

<answer>



my daughter just got hair extensions but she was advised against that type, it puts too much pressure on your own hair and can break the hair off, plus when you get them taken out they use this stuff polymer, i think that's how you spell it, but it can cause a reaction, the hairdresser told a story about a girl taken a reaction when she was taken them out, had to be rushed to hospital, any way, my daughter got micro ring wafts, its much kinder to the hair, plus you don't notice it at all, she got them 18" so it looks really good, they cost a bit more than the other ones, but if your hair is thick and you want loads of volume then that's the way to go, she has had them for about three weeks now and thinks there great, she gos into the hairdressers once a week and they blow dry them for hair, then she washes it herself and curls them herself as well. I hope this helps, oh plus get the more expensive hair, it will last longer, and looks better. what ever you decide, make sure its a good place your getting them done, or you could spend a lot of money for nothing, kates cost £500.

<answer>



well, bleach questions on here should be way more descriptive, no offense to you or anything, but just in general, there's a lot of things that go into bleaching hair. first off, how light is your blonde hair? how dark are your roots?. i'd say that if you have dark roots bleach them and then bleach your blonde AFTER you get your roots the color you want them. i'll assume that since you say it's blonde that it's fairly light. so, i wouldn't bleach with more than a 20-25 for 30 minutes tops. I'd say use 10 volume, but the truth is, is that i used 10 volume with purple bleach on my already bleached yellow hair to turn it white(long story, if you want to hear it just message me via e-mail or leave yours if you comment my answer) and it did NOTHING. and you have artificial color in your hair and i'm assuming that you want to color it lighter? so i'd say 20 or 25 volume. with, i'd say purple bleach? ya, lol. hope i helped!



P.S. IT WON'T FALL OUT IN CHUNKS! i've bleached my hair one day with 30 volume developer for an hour, colored it 12G blonde the next day with 40 volume developer for 30 minutes, didn't work, so i bleached it AGAIN the next day with neutral bleach for an HOUR, then the next day, bleached it with PURPLE bleach for ANOTHER 30 minutes! and the worst thing that happened to me was dandruff because my scalp was dry :-(



Source(s):



bleached my hair once, bad experience, lost hair at roots and haven't grown back, since then, did research on hair bleach and how it works almost everyday for 2 years. I have WHITE hair with NO THANKS to toners!!! yay! and it's STILL soft!



</answer>
